title: Green Trees and Blue Mountains
text:
Li Shan, the painter of this landscape has long been considered one of the most innovative of the group of artists known as the "Eight Eccentrics of Yang-chou." A talented writer, Li was appointed to service in the Imperial Academy in the early 1720s. A rather dissolute lifestyle led to a loss of his inherited fortune however, and by 1726 Li was living in Yang-chou in the T'ien-ming temple struggling to earn his living as a professional artist. Li evolved a personal style based on heavily textured brushwork that gave primacy to purely aesthetic values. The present landscape is one of at least four extant paintings that were originally part of the same album. These works all show the influence of the famous artist Pa-ta Shan-jen (1626-1705), a personal friend of Li Shan. The inscription reads:

Green trees grow thickly, shading mountain cottages,

I don't know if people are present in the

smart-weed blossom village;

I thought carefully the whole night through

and with rain from the river's source.

Washed forth the blue mountains

with close-knit dots and lines.

The Taoist from Ao
description: jagged mountains in blue, grey and very light pink; trees and buildings in middle ground; inscription with seal in upper left corner
